This issue is in two parts:

- [ ] Allow the server to generate the resource
- [ ] Show the "identity" information in remote client picker menus if available

Allowing the server to generate the resource ensures that there are no conflicts, and that local server policy is met. More importantly, it protects against [presence leaks](http://xmpp.org/rfcs/rfc6120.html#security-leaks-presence) (assuming the server is actually choosing a random, unguessable resource). The users identity can then be discovered with Service Disco and the `name` attribute can be shown in the list.

eg. an example from the XSF's client recommendations:

```
<iq type='result'
    from='romeo@montague.net/orchard'
    to='juliet@capulet.com/balcony'
    id='info4'>
  <query xmlns='http://jabber.org/protocol/disco#info'>
    <identity
        category='client'
        type='pc'
        name='Work PC'/>
    <feature var='jabber:iq:time'/>
    <feature var='jabber:iq:version'/>
  </query>
</iq>
```

When picking where to send a file, the menu for the client that responded with this service disco might be "Work PC (pc)" or something similar.
title: Let server generate resource and show identity instead of resource when picking a remote client

Since the most recent updates to Conversations, notification behavior has changed. The previous behavior was to notify the user for the following situations:

A message sent directly to the user from another user;
A message broadcast to multiple users;
A message posted to a MUC room that included the users nickname.

This behavior is the default behavior for most XMPP clients.

Since the most recent updates to Conversations this behaviour has changed. Now every message in a MUC triggers a notification.

This behavior is undesirable. It renders notifications of little value as if you are idling in a busy MUC your phone will be notified constantly, even if the messages are not intended for you. The only option to prevent the device constantly receiving notifications are to either turn off notifications for the MUC in question, or to disable notifications in the app. Turning off notifications for the room is also undesirable, as it triggers a warning whenever you enter the MUC, by way of a persistent line at the bottom of the chat, and also because it will also prevent notifications when messages are sent including your username.

The previous behavior reflects the standard notification behavior demonstrated in other XMPP apps (for instance, Pidjin, Trillion, Psi) and I believe it should either be restored or a toggle added to enable users to choose between the two notification behaviors.

I am using Conversations 1.6.7 on a Sony Xperia Z1 running the latest nighties of Cyanogenmod 12.1 and I am connecting to a private XMPP server for a large online MMO guild.
title: Notification behavior has changed to notify for every message in a MUC

This also enables the [SNI](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6066#page-6) and [ALPN](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7301) TLS extensions so xmpp can be hosted on the same port as other services.

Look at _xmpp-client._tcp.burtrum.org and _xmpp-client._tls.burtrum.org for examples, the way I have it set up _xmpp-client._tls. has a greater priority.

Let me know what needs done to get this merged, a gajim patch is in the works now as well...

I intend to write a XEP for this as well, but the short version is this:

Lookup _xmpp-client._tls. in addition to _xmpp-client._tcp, mix priorities and weights like they were the same SRV record.  For _tls records obviously connect over TLS, for _tcp nothing changes.

  1. TLS certificates MUST be validated the same way as for STARTTLS. (ie, against the jid domain part)
  2. STARTTLS MUST NOT be used over TLS connections.
  3. Client SHOULD set SNI TLS extension to the host in the SRV record.
  4. Client SHOULD set the ALPN TLS extension, when ALPN is used protocol MUST be 'xmpp' (this value needs registered with [IANA](https://www.iana.org/assignments/tls-extensiontype-values/tls-extensiontype-values.xhtml), though I'm not entirely sure how to go about that or whether the XEP or IANA thing comes first...)
title: Add support for '_xmpp-client._tls.' SRV records for XMPP over TLS

I got OpenPGP set up with my Conversations (0.7.3), my friend did not, i enable OpenPGP for the conversation with her and Conversations tells me that she has not set up OpenPGP yet and i shall tell her to do so. I did what i was told. She fought herself through the still much too complicated and non-self-explaining process (at least for usual users..) of the OpenKeychain (3.0.1) key generation. She restarts Conversations, selects her newly generated private key, enables OpenPGP in our conversation and with her first message, my public key gets automatically transferred to her and i receive the encrypted message from her. Everything fine on the Conversations side for now.

Now if i try to reply to that encrypted message, my Conversation still tells me that i don't have her public key, which is correct. But the automatic key transfer from her to me doesn't start. Disabling and reenabling OpenPGP for that conversation did not help either. I had to kill the app in the app manager and restart it, before the automatic key transfer started with the next message i sent her.

If this feature doesn't work instantly, the user might think they have to transfer the key manually, which happened in our case is a lot of hassle with all the bugs of OpenKeychain and did not work at all.
title: Automatic OpenPGP public key sharing not working without restart

SCRAM-SHA1-PLUS is one of the few auth methods that is MITM safe. It hashes TLS informations into the sasl response which means only the other end of the connection can verify the credentials, meaning a normal MITM will fail on auth. (This is called channel binding, which is available if the -PLUS suffix is used).

This is only useful if the application also pins the auth method, e.g. if a server proposed SCRAM-SHA1-PLUS it will no longer fall back to a weaker auth method.

Beem seems to use the swift.im implementation. I'm not sure if their licence is compatible.
title: Support SCRAM-SHA1-PLUS
